reviewText: Almost unplayable. It's shallow, simplistic, your car controls like a goat on roller skates and the frame rate is an embarrassment. I beat the first level (eventually), but the experience was simply so un-fun that after persisting with the second level for a few minutes I decided that enough was enough and just hit alt-F4. The game's free and I STILL want my money back!

reviewText:
Product received for free

Explore a desolate environment and build the road on the go in this exciting racing game

Although you might assume there‚Äôs not much left to innovate when it comes to racing games, the truth is that there‚Äôs always something one change, not to mention all the things that can be added. Not just that, but genre mixing is quite popular as well, which opens up an even larger palette of possibilities when it comes to gameplay mechanics.
Build the road ahead one piece at a time

Skyreach is not your typical racing game, but it‚Äôs not exactly a revelation in the genre either. In short, the main idea is that you are free to build the track as you go along, making it more of an exploration game than anything else. Unfortunately, it has a few flaws that make the experience a tad too annoying to be enjoyable, especially if you go in expecting speed and actual driving.

To begin with, the action takes place in some kind of great desert, although you are actually racing between floating islands. The fact that there‚Äôs no ground means that you have to place each piece of the track as you go, otherwise you fall to your death. If this sounds anticlimactic and slow, it‚Äôs because it is. Hence, you‚Äôre usually moving along at a snail‚Äôs place, partly because it‚Äôs difficult to maintain speed and build the track, and partly because the game takes forever to place the said track pieces anyway.
Over-sensitive controls and decent graphics

You also have to deal with the poorly optimized controls, given the fact that the vehicle oversteers at the slightest touch, making it incredibly frustrating to negotiate corners at slightly higher speeds. Thankfully, at least you can use a controller to have a better grip on the situation, but that only makes it better than with a keyboard, not better in general. It shouldn‚Äôt come as a surprise that controls are important in a racing game.

Things are much better in the graphics department, and it‚Äôs obvious that the designers put some soul into the environments and the game world in general. The desolate landscapes can be quite moody and engaging, even if you‚Äôll barely get the chance to admire them while you build the track. The graphics quality is decent as well, although there are some performance issues that shouldn‚Äôt be there.
A great concept that needs a lot of work

All things considered, Skyreach is certainly something new, and it‚Äôs only natural that it didn‚Äôt come out perfect the first time around. However, something has to change as quickly as possible, because right now the game is not able to keep players happy for more than a few minutes.

With out a few updates this game is unplayable. As of now i cannot recommend the game in its current state at all. If you want a racing game look elsewhere cause you wont find it in Skyreach.

reviewText:
An awful experience.  A dreadfully awful experience.

Is this game free?  Yes.
Does this game have achievements?  Yes.
Are all the negative reviews accurate?  Yes.
Does this game have awful framerate on most machines?  Yes.
Does this game require you to manually edit the game's registry just so it can run smoothly?  Yes.
Is this fix temporary to where it will still lag?  Yes.
Are the controls over sensitive?  Yes.
Is this a racing game with a narrow road?  Yes.
Will the music get annoying?  Yes.
Is the environment an uninspired and frustrating wasteland? Yes.
Should you avoid this game?  Yes.
Is this game Skyreach?  Yes.

Hope this answers all your concerns...by the way, you only have 3 levels, but get an achievement for All stages complete" for beating the first two.  Do you really want an easy 100%?  Hope you're up to digging into your registry.  This is obviously a student project that is meant to attempt being innovative
date:
yet p*ss off its own players.


0.5/10  Skyreach?  More like Rectalreach."

reviewText: WARNING: This is not a racing game at all! Don't come into this expecting racing gameplay-like features.\n\nWhat this game is: You drive around a scene, trying to collect green crystals that give you the time needed to reach the end of the scene. But the path you drive on is created by you, section by section, as you go (you choose between a left turn, a right turn, and a straight ahead path). It's like an exploratory race against time"
date: except you're only racing against the clock.\n\nIt feels and plays like an early stage indie game. There are some good ideas for a game here
hoursPlayed: even if it was not a great overall experience. That said

reviewText:
Interesting concept.  Nice artwork/style.

But... quite slow, and not much fun.... but with a lot of potential.

I found myself having to slow down and wait to 'draw' the next track piece.  If my mind is 2 or 3 pieces ahead, I wanted to draw them and drive them quickly, but I couldn't.

Dying because I didn't make it to the next gem in time, caused frustration, not the need to replay.   I wanted to keep drawing track and trying to make it to the gem... after a few rounds, then I could trying to find the optimum route... but, nope... don't get it right... game over.

I also wanted the ability to build the track up and down, not just left, right, forward.

Just my 2 cents.  At this point, fun to try for free.  Possibly quite a good and interesting driving puzzle game with some work.  For now though, I can't recommend.

reviewText: Skyreach is a nice little unity game, that plays and feels like a student game. Unfortunately, its coming from a studio that is supposed to be professional by now.\nThe good original idea ( building the track you race on as you go ) does not make up for  the lack of good feedback,instateneous deaths, poor graphics ( is this really unity on fantastic mode ?) and frustrating level design.\nThis feels like a first playtest in a second year of school. Too bad, since it's an okay concept.

reviewText:
Skyreach,

in short, nice concept, not so biljant excution.

What is it what I don't like about this game?
Well, it's the controls and the presentation.
In my opinion the controls are not precise enough and the way things are presented gives me the feeling that it's just some hobby project.
Basically, that's okay if it wasn't for the many strange crashes that I get or the absence of any hints if needed.
Might be just me, but I'm not a sucker for this kind of game.

reviewText:
Product received for free

Nice concept, but I spotted some flaws:
1. Graphics are too processor heavy, resulting in fps loss.
2. Reaction time for every action is significantly long.
3. Curved tiles aren't as long as straight tiles. That makes some paths impossible, and thus takes away the freedom of building your own road. (Not necessarily a bad thing)
